Graphics are hard to read and pretty generic. The game is about optimising your way through the spread sheet with some luck and randomness included as is in fashion these days. Both Brügge and Ginkopolis are better versions of card play with the board.

Like a loooong slog through thigh deep mud, only to arrive just as someone beats you to it. Which wouldn't be so bad if it didn't take several turns to set up for every move. Then you can try something else if you have the correct resources, or go on with your plan if you have the money to pay double. Cards cannot be counted on as by the time your turn rolls around it may be a completely new set and not ones you can afford or even use. Locations may favor the start players and that may or may not be mitigated by the "double prizes" for the last player. Almost no way to plan ahead. Given the random board setup and rotating cards, I would argue there is luck involved. Luck in turn order vs. board lay out and how the cards come out. Played 2 games, one 4 player and one 5 player. Won one, lost one. I don't hate Euros by any stretch, but you could not pay me to play this one again! Pure torture.

Playing the game makes you feel like a logistics officer wearing a toga. It's dry as a cracker, low on player-to-player interaction and high on bureaucratic optimisation. The actual process of play is self-centered and passive. It's the same back and forth without flexibility. There is nothing really to talk about during the game or after the game. It reminds of those tedious deckbuilding games, but without the shuffling.

The goal of the game is initially opaque. It's neither complicated nor complex. It's just so that persons can memorize a handful of scoring options beforehand and show the noobz which side their bread is buttered on. There is points for everything, but all matters more or less depending on the right cards. Main interaction takes place in form of a race betweeen players for the cards that will reward their strategy most.

A non-intuitive, headache inducing mix of arbitrary and convoluted resource allocation rules to optimize your final score. It is so easy to feel like you just did something wrong and wasted a turn which will likely cost you the game. When a game feels like a grueling math exam and hard work all at the same time, it is no longer fun. Euro gamers love obtuse spreadsheet calculation games that would bore the average person to death and for them this delivers.

Not only is this the epitome of a "trading in the Mediterranean" game, the game is not even about wealth accumulation since the trading goods part is just subterfuge for getting your pieces on the board and acquiring more god cards that optimize your final scoring using those pieces. But you cannot even focus on a single strategy and hope to win, you need to focus on 3 or more at the same time. How is this fun?

As with most euro trading games the prices are all apparently set by some commie czar and do not fluctuate as they would in a real economy. This is why players who enjoy these games usually cannot handle actual market based economies. They instead "play" command economy games like this fooling themselves into thinking they are clever.

The game includes nonsense-euro mechanics where you add another colonist to the board and now your individual colonists have the ability to travel farther. Wait what, how does that make any thematic sense? Or that when you put out more colonists you now have more warehouse space. Huh? Were your colonists living in your warehouse? How come you can keep building new trading posts but you cannot build a bigger warehouse? And why can you only build 15 trading posts? Did the Roman Emperor set a limit on these? The game makes little sense and for that I see little sense in continuing to play it.
Rating after initial play. Very multiplayer solitaire with minimal interaction. The pseudo historical theme saves it from a 1. I love historical war games and this makes me think about those.

I could not get on with this game, unfortunately. I found it very, very dry, with no dramatic moments, very little meaningful player interaction, and almost every available action was dull. I'm growing old and getting more mellow. Concordia is easily the mid-weight efficiency Euro that I will gladly play out of all its peers. Sheer elegance and the game is surprisingly colourful without it being an absolute eyesore like so many of these new modern Euros that looks like someone puked on them after drinking a bottle of food colouring

====================

UPDATE: Mar 2022

The game is just too linear for me nowadays. It's easy to just pick a combo of gods as your strategy, max it all out, and win with it.

Concordia is now Mac Gerdts' least interesting work from his ludography. Anything (other than Hamburgum) is better than this. Yes. Transatlantic is better.

Imperial/Imperial 2030 is still Gerdts' best one for its sheer depth and opacity.

==============================

UPDATE: Aug 2021

Concordia is still a Mac Gerdts design: simple, strategic. has sufficient player interaction. However, I am cooling with Concordia. I have perhaps played it for approx 25 times and the strategy is no longer as deep as I thought it is now that I am exposed to other games by Mac Gerdts too, but also more Cube Rails and 18xx.

The tightest mid-weight Euro I've ever played. On your turn, you play a card and you do what it says. End of turn. Fantastic Euro game that doesn't stop other players from being blocked, but rather just make it more costly for them.

Concerns of the lack of player interaction seems to be mooted with experienced players. Experience players will make sure to leech on your actions.

I know this is heresy, but Concordia left me completely cold.

It’s elegant, yes. Streamlined, sure. A Euro classic, absolutely. But after a few plays, I walked away feeling like I’d spent 90 minutes organizing a spreadsheet in ancient Rome—with no idea if I was winning until the final tally blindsided me.

I get why people love it. The player interaction is subtle but sharp, and the decision space opens up nicely with experience. But for me? It felt like playing in the dark, with no feedback loop and no spark. Maybe I’m too impatient, maybe I need more plays… or maybe I just don’t enjoy sweating over Roman logistics in total silence.

Read my full grievances in my review https://rolltoreview.com/concordia-board-game-review/

Concordia was all the rage in the mid-2010s and often described as the best mid-weight Eurogame. Plus it was from the designer of Imperial, which inspired confidence. Knowing this was probably not my jam anyway, I bought a box as a gift for a friend who had proven a bit more optimisation-happy than I was. His copy is to my knowledge still in shrink, and now that I've had the opportunity to play the game, I'm now wondering whether he'll find anyone in his family/friends whose enthusiasm will not have taken a nosedive halfway through the rules teach.

To be fair, the points of player interaction in Concordia are non-null, but more of less limited to the following:
• Players can't stop movement on the same road segment.
• Depleting an increasing amount of regions makes it more tempting for another player to refresh them all for a massive cash injection.
• Triggering resource generation does so for all valid players.
• The later you are to build in a city, the more expensive.
• Additional action/VP cards are first-come first-served.

Only the latter two really qualify as relevant to your thought process, so, what we're having here is essentially a race of converting resources into resources into victory points (*my favourite*...) through the acquisition of specialised personal scoring conditions. And that race is somewhere on the spectrum of a half-convincing attempt at justifying not being multiplayer solitaire. But the level of mathematical obfuscation of the final scoring (the lifting of which would slow down the pacing to an excruciating level) means that in practice other players’ positions don't really matter outside of the cards they're likely to snatch first. Frankly, I just felt like I was playing a long and complicated version of Splendor with needless additional steps that have little upside. If Concordia is the best in its genre, I fear my personal taste has nothing but expletives for its genre.

Modern Eurogamers will love it, though.

- After second play with Salsa expansion: a little better as scoring was clearer but did not make me come around on this game. Pens out, calculators on, let's start counting it all out because nobody knows nothing about what the others did the last two hours - except for the one or two special cards they obtained.

- let me start good things: quick turns, very clear and few rules (entire rule set was taught to me in 10 min). Liked the hand management aspect of it and that everything happened on a shared board, no individual tableaus (easier to parse all the information), also the "copy and paste" cards made it very interesting
- neutral: art and theme. Do not understand complaints about the art style. Not overwhelmingly beautiful but totally fine. While the theme does little in terms of immersion it at least provides a coherent framework. Also do not understand complaints in that department.
- negatives: at its heart Concordia is a spreadsheet game that rewards computing as many of your turns in advance as possible. Most of the time you are chaining your actions to achieve a state of resource wealth to be able to build or buy a set of cards (produce in province x, then swapping resource x for money to buy resource z, then buy the card to be able to…). If you love efficiency programming, this is your game.
Vp scoring is somewhat convoluted (during first play) and I assume it must be hard to keep track other players' scores. Only indirect interaction through going to places first (increasing cost for others) and snatching cards. What ultimately lead to my contrarian overall assessment of the game: It was a pretty dry heads down business for me. And there was little feeling of achievement. In spite of the rather quick turns I got bored and impatient quite fast. In spite of my admiration for the slick game design, it did not create much engagement or above average fun.

On 2nd play with Salsa expansion it was more fun but still not my cup of tea.

The game is also starting to suffer from an array of unnecessary and terrible expansions being released, which completionists insist on playing with. Forum tiles work entirely against the idea of trying to efficiently play your cards before recalling them, salt isn't an interesting addition, and the Venus team play was underwhelming.

The more I play it, the less I like it. I like the strategic potential deck building games provide, but so few get them right. The game gets longer and longer with more and more downtime inbetween turns, with no ability to interrupt my opponents, and being a gut player, I don't waste my time constantly re-evaluating my strategy as my opponents take their turns, so the game becomes less interesting with each subsequent turn, and despite the strategic path drafting specific cards allows you to take, you still have to adjust your tactics every turn due to minor mathy annoyances rather than intentional player dickery. I stopped playing my copy, and gave it away once I realized the type of players that gravitate towards it weren't interested in the more interactive games I actually want to play.

This variant would convince me to play it again.

Admittedly, my partner and I enjoy games with an element of ongoing chance/luck that, like life, affects our decision-making. If Concordia had a chance mechanism it would be more fun for us. We really wanted to like it.

Also, the scoring system is kind of dull. You don't know until the end how many points players have. We like games where there's more obvious scoring tension as the game goes on.

That said, it would make a solid second or third Euro game for people new to the genre.

Because of this it lacks any highs or lows or moments you'll talk about a month after playing. This places it in a weird area where it's too breezy for the heavy gamers in my life but too long for the more casual gamers to get into it.

A well designed game for sure. I enjoy the mix of area control, and building up both my deck and economy. There's many different paths to victory, and I like that points are obscured, meaning players can pull off surprise wins. Elegant certainly, this game flows very well.

End of the day though I just find Concordia very bland. There's little interaction besides blocking; I wish there was some form of direct trading/conflict. Without that it's just a pure resource conversion efficiency puzzle. Players making a territory more expensive does slightly change the math, but that's it.

Note this is not a deal breaker, nor that bad, just a small negative. The biggest problem is that there are just so many better games (for us) that play in the same time. It just wasn't coming off the shelf, so someone else should have chance to see if it fits their group better. Traded away.

Concordia is a masterclass in minimalism. The depth of this game, considering its simplicity, is truly impressive and it rightfully deserves the accolades it's received. There isn't an ounce of fat on this game; the rules are straightforward, yet the decision space is vast. However, like many euros, Concordia makes no real attempt at theme integration. At no point did I feel connected to the idea of building a Roman dynasty or honoring ancient gods, which left the experience feeling distant and mechanical. Additionally, the actions you take turn after turn remain largely the same from start to finish, resulting in a gameplay flow that feels less dynamic and engaging as the game progresses. Given the choice, I would take Troyes or Tzolk’in over Concordia any day as my top-tier euros.

I really don't love games where everything is so opaque until the end when the six different points scoring methods are revealed. A classic euro game where players are playing cards each turn and executing its action (trading resources, buying more cards, moving on land/sea and building, inducing income for all players who in a region or collect all coins placed, copy a prior player's card, pick up all cards and place another meeple on the board, etc. Scoring is influenced by what players have done and points only come from cards they have (initial and any cards bought). Once all cards are played, the player with the most points wins.

Mostly played at 2p on the Corsica and Creta maps. Concordia gave very good early impressions with its clean, accessible design. I tend to like the action retrieval mechanism, and here it works well. Unfortunately, the shine wore off a few games in. The gears in this efficiency engine became all too visible too quickly.

Concordia is that nice girl/guy, pleasant but lacking oomph and a little bland. A great casual friend perhaps, but not someone to take home to mom and dad (unless, of course, that is your type).

That said, Concordia is staying in the collection for now, in part because it achieves the rare feat of scaling well from 2 to 5 players. Maybe a little salt will help.

Feb. 2025 #46: One of my early favorites in the hobby, Concordia continues to squeak into my top 50. It's practically ubiquitous now, but Concordia's "play one or pick up" hand-building continues to be one of my favorite action selection mechanisms. The Diplomat is also fascinating at higher counts; you'll need to keep an eagle eye on what other players do to grab another Architect or Senator action. Concordia also lets players choose how they'll score, through card purchases, another favorite mechanism. It's just so solid, and works well at all player counts, assuming you've got a tight enough map.

Jul. 2024 #47

Jan. 2024 #46: Concordia was also a top game for me early in the hobby. I still really enjoy it, particularly on a very tight map. Racing for cities, clever timing of the Diplomat, using the Prefect at the perfect moment--these are all points of interaction that I love. And the hand management is excellent. It's just been surpassed by the more substantial interaction in some of the above "cubes on a map" games.

Scales well with two maps for higher or lower player counts.

Concordia is a quintessential Euro game. If you like to generate resources and convert them into points, it is the best of its kind. Since the action cards double as your scoring incentives at the end of the game, the core challenge of Concordia is balancing a broad, well-rounded action economy with a narrow, focused point-scoring strategy. The puzzle is maddening and counterintuitive, and I love it.

Base box contains expansions & maps.
- Concordia: Salsa
- Concordia: Aegyptus / Creta (2017)
- Concordia: Britannia / Germania (2014)
- Concordia: Solitaria (2021)
